worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Performing arithmetic operations with large numbers
Translating number names into numerals and vice versa

partitions.text: The place value of 5 in 5,432 is

content.question: Which of the following numbers is the greatest?
Write the number name for 7,654,321 in the Indian numeration system.
content.answer: Seventy-six lakh fifty-four thousand three hundred twenty-one

content.statement: In the Indian system of numeration, one crore is equal to ten million.

content.question: Draw a place value chart for the number 3,45,678 using the Indian numeration system.
content.answer: Lakh: 3, Ten Thousand: 4, Thousand: 5, Hundred: 6, Ten: 7, Units: 8

content.question: Match the numbers with their expanded forms.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Which number is on the right of 4 on the number line?
Match the operations with their results.
Explain why zero is included in whole numbers but not in natural numbers.

rubrics.title: Explanation of Zero in Whole Numbers
Explanation of Zero in Natural Numbers

content.answer: Zero is included in whole numbers as it represents the absence of quantity, which is essential for counting and arithmetic operations. Natural numbers start from 1 and are used for counting objects, hence zero is not included.

content.statement: All whole numbers are natural numbers.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: The next number in the sequence.
The previous number in the sequence.

content.question: Label the following numbers on the number line: 0, 3, 5, 7.
content.answer: 0, 3, 5, and 7 should be labeled accurately on the number line as per their sequential order.

content.question: Circle the correct operation for finding the sum of 3 and 4.
Draw a number line and mark the numbers from 0 to 10.
content.answer: A straight line with evenly spaced marks representing numbers from 0 to 10.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Understanding and identifying factors and multiples
Differentiating between prime and composite numbers

content.question: Which of the following numbers is a prime number?

content.statement: A number is divisible by 5 if it ends in 0 or 5.

content.question: Find the HCF of 18 and 24.
content.answer: The HCF of 18 and 24 is 6.

content.question: Mark the prime numbers from 1 to 100 in the table.

rubrics.title: Accurate labeling of the factor tree
Correct calculation of LCM using the prime factors

content.answer: The LCM of 12 and 18 is 36.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Analyzing properties of lines and angles
Differentiating between open and closed curves

partitions.text: A point is denoted by a capital letter and it determines a

content.question: What is obtained when a line segment is extended indefinitely in both directions?
Match the polygon with its number of sides.
Explain how an angle is formed and name its parts.
content.answer: An angle is formed when two rays meet at a common endpoint. The common endpoint is called the vertex, and the two rays are called the arms of the angle.

content.statement: Parallel lines never meet, no matter how far they are extended.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Line segment extending from a point
Exact location marked by a dot

content.question: Label the curves as open or closed.
content.answer: Open curves do not enclose a space and do not meet at the start and end point, while closed curves enclose a space and meet at the start and end point.

content.question: Draw a line segment AB and mark its midpoint M.

rubrics.title: Correct drawing of line segment AB

content.answer: A line segment AB is drawn with endpoints A and B, and the midpoint M is marked equidistant from A and B.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Which type of triangle has all sides of different lengths?

partitions.text: An angle measuring 90° is called a

content.statement: A reflex angle is smaller than a right angle.

content.question: Match the quadrilateral with its properties.
Draw a scalene triangle and label its sides.
content.answer: A triangle with all sides of different lengths, labeled as a, b, and c.

content.question: Label the types of angles in the diagram.
content.answer: Acute, Right, Obtuse, Reflex.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Converting between improper fractions and mixed numbers

content.question: Which of the following is an equivalent fraction of 1/2?

content.statement: The fraction 3/4 is greater than 2/3.

content.question: Add 2/5 and 3/10 and simplify the result.
content.answer: 2/5 + 3/10 = 4/10 + 3/10 = 7/10, which is already in simplest form.

content.question: Write the fraction representing the shaded portion.
content.answer: The shaded portion represents the fraction 3/4.

content.question: Draw a number line and show the fractions 1/2, 2/4, and 4/8.

rubrics.title: Correctly places 1/2 on the number line
Correctly places 2/4 on the number line
Correctly places 4/8 on the number line

content.answer: The fractions 1/2, 2/4, and 4/8 are all equivalent and should be placed at the same point on the number line.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI
topics: Using Decimals in Money, Length, and Weight

content.question: Which is greater: 0.3 or 0.4?

questions.topic: Using Decimals in Money, Length, and Weight

content.question: Match the following conversions.
Add 0.68 and 0.54 and express the result in decimal form.

questions.topic: Using Decimals in Money, Length, and Weight

content.statement: 5 paise is equal to 0.05 rupees.

content.question: Complete the crossword using decimal hints.
Shade the decimal grid to represent 0.74.
content.answer: Tenths: 0.7, Hundredths: 0.04

content.question: Circle the greater number in each pair.

questions.topic: Using Decimals in Money, Length, and Weight

content.question: Draw a diagram showing the conversion of 156 cm to meters using decimals.
content.answer: 1.56 meters

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: A data is a collection of numbers gathered to give some

content.question: What method did Salma use to organize the fruit choices?
Match the pictograph symbols to their meanings.
Explain how a pictograph can help in understanding data quickly.
content.answer: A pictograph uses pictures or symbols to represent data, making it easy to understand at a glance. For example, a pictograph of apples can show the number of apples sold each day using apple icons.

content.statement: Tally marks are used to organize data in groups of five.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.
Each hand represents 10 students present in the class. Mark the number of students present in the class on each day.
content.answer: Labels should include the title, key, and correct representation of data using symbols.

content.question: Draw a pictograph to represent the data of students' favorite fruits.
content.answer: The pictograph should accurately represent the data using symbols, with a clear key explaining the symbols used.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: The perimeter of a rectangle is calculated as 2 × (length +

content.question: What is the area of a square with a side length of 5 cm?
Match the following dimensions with their areas.
Explain how to find the perimeter of a square.
content.answer: The perimeter of a square is found by multiplying the length of one side by 4.

content.statement: The perimeter of a square is four times the length of one side.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: A shape with four equal sides.
The distance around a closed figure.

content.question: Label the sides of the rectangle and calculate its area.
content.answer: Label the longer side as length and the shorter side as breadth. Calculate the area using the formula: Area = length × breadth.

content.question: Circle the correct formula for the area of a square.
content.text:
Area = side × side
Area = side + side
Area = side ÷ side

content.question: Draw a rectangle with a perimeter of 20 cm.
content.answer: A possible rectangle could have dimensions 5 cm by 5 cm, since the perimeter is 2 × (5 + 5) = 20 cm.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Applying algebraic expressions to solve problems

partitions.text: The expression for the number of matchsticks required for n Ls is

content.question: What is the rule for the number of matchsticks needed for forming n Cs?
Explain the concept of a variable and give an example.
content.answer: A variable is a symbol used to represent a number in expressions or equations. For example, in the expression 2x + 3, x is a variable.

content.statement: A variable can only take values from 1 to 10.

content.question: Match the letters with the number of matchsticks used.
Draw a pattern using matchsticks for the letter 'T' and write the expression for n Ts.
content.answer: The pattern for 'T' is drawn using 2 matchsticks, and the expression for n Ts is 2n.

worksheet.subject: Mathematics
worksheet.book: NCERT: Mathematics - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Which of the following sets of numbers are in proportion?
Match the items with their correct unitary conversions.
Explain why 4:6 is equivalent to 2:3.
content.answer: 4:6 is equivalent to 2:3 because both ratios simplify to the same value when the greatest common divisor is used. Dividing both terms of 4:6 by 2 results in 2:3.

content.statement: The ratio 10:5 is the same as 2:1.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Method to find value of one unit
Ratios that represent the same value

content.question: Circle the correct ratio.
Draw a diagram to show equivalent ratios of 2:3.
content.answer: A diagram showing two parts of one color and three parts of another, maintaining the 2:3 ratio.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a balanced diet?
Match the vitamin/mineral to its deficiency disease.
Why is it important to include roughage in our diet?
content.answer: Roughage, or dietary fiber, is important because it helps in digestion by adding bulk to the stool and preventing constipation. It also helps in maintaining a healthy weight and lowering the risk of diabetes and heart disease.

content.statement: A balanced diet contains all nutrients in equal amounts.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Needed in small amounts for health.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: Materials that allow light to pass through them are called

content.question: Which of the following materials is typically opaque?
Match the objects with the materials they are made of.
Explain why some materials float on water while others sink.
content.answer: Materials float on water if their density is less than that of water. For example, wood floats because it is less dense than water, while metal sinks because it is denser.

content.statement: All metals are shiny.

content.question: Complete the crossword using properties of materials.

wordPlacements.hint: Does not allow light to pass through

content.question: Circle the materials that are transparent.
Draw a diagram showing three objects made from different materials.
content.answer: A diagram showing a wooden chair, a plastic bottle, and a metal pan.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: The process of separating seeds of paddy from its stalks is called

content.question: Which method is used to separate tea leaves from prepared tea?
Match the separation process with its purpose.
Explain how evaporation is used to obtain salt from seawater.
content.answer: Evaporation is used to obtain salt from seawater by allowing the water to evaporate, leaving the salt behind. The sun's heat causes the water to evaporate, and the salt is left as a residue.

content.statement: Sedimentation involves the settling of heavier particles at the bottom.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Used to get salt from seawater

content.question: Label the parts involved in winnowing process shown.
content.answer: Correctly label the parts such as the grain, husk, and wind direction in the winnowing process.

content.question: Draw and label a diagram showing a saturated solution.
content.answer: Draw a beaker with water and salt, showing undissolved salt at the bottom to indicate saturation.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: Plants with green and tender stems are called

content.question: What is the broad, green part of the leaf called?
Match the plant part with its function.
Explain the process of photosynthesis in leaves.

rubrics.title: Description of Light and Water Role

content.answer: Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants use sunlight to synthesize foods with the help of chlorophyll present in the leaves. During this process, plants take in carbon dioxide and water, and with the help of sunlight, convert them into glucose and oxygen.

content.statement: Transpiration is the process of water vapor leaving the plant through leaves.

content.question: Label the parts of the plant shown in the diagram.
content.answer: Leaf, Stem, Root

content.question: Draw and label a diagram of a tree, shrub, and herb.
content.answer: A diagram showing a tree with a thick trunk, a shrub with multiple stems, and a herb with a green tender stem, each labeled accordingly.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: Joints of the bones help in the

content.question: Which animal uses a muscular foot for movement?
Match the body part with its type of joint.
Explain how muscles work in pairs to move bones.
content.answer: Muscles work in pairs to move bones. When one muscle of the pair contracts, the other muscle relaxes, creating movement at the joint.

content.statement: The cartilage is harder than bones.

content.question: Complete the crossword using clues about animal movements.
Label the parts of the ball and socket joint.
content.answer: Label the parts such as the ball, socket, and surrounding ligaments accurately.

content.question: Draw and label a diagram of the ball and socket joint.
content.answer: Draw a diagram showing the ball and socket joint, labeling the ball, socket, and ligaments.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: The Living Organisms — Characteristics and Habitats
skills: Identification of living and non-living characteristics
Analysis of organism characteristics and their survival mechanisms

partitions.text: The presence of specific features, which enable a plant or an animal to live in a particular habitat, is called

content.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of living organisms?
Match the organisms with their habitats.
Explain how a cactus is adapted to survive in a desert environment.

rubrics.title: Description of Spines and Their Function

content.answer: Cacti have adaptations like thick, fleshy stems for water storage, spines instead of leaves to reduce water loss, and a deep root system to absorb water efficiently. They can survive extreme temperatures by opening their stomata at night to reduce water loss.

content.statement: All living organisms need food to survive.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

content.question: What type of motion does a pendulum exhibit?
Match the transport mode with its development era.
Why is it important to use standard units of measurement?
content.answer: Standard units of measurement are important because they provide a consistent framework for measurement, ensuring clear communication and accuracy in scientific and everyday contexts.

content.statement: A car moving on a straight road exhibits circular motion.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Type of motion in a circle

content.question: Circle the correct SI unit of length.
Draw and label a diagram showing circular motion.
content.answer: A diagram showing a circular path with arrows indicating motion and labels for key components such as center, radius, and direction of motion.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Understanding of light and its properties
Classification of materials based on light transmission
Construction and use of a pinhole camera

content.question: Which of the following is a luminous object?

partitions.text: An object that does not allow light to pass through is called

content.statement: Shadows form when light is completely blocked by an opaque object.

content.question: Explain how a mirror changes the direction of light.
content.answer: A mirror changes the direction of light by reflecting it. When light rays hit a smooth surface like a mirror, they bounce back at the same angle at which they hit the surface. This process is called reflection.

content.question: Draw and label a simple pinhole camera setup.
content.answer: The drawing should include a box with a small hole on one side and a translucent screen on the opposite side. Light from an object enters through the pinhole and forms an inverted image on the screen.

content.question: Match the objects with their light transmission properties.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI
skills: Understanding electrical components and their functions

partitions.text: A device that is used to break an electric circuit is called a

content.question: What are the two terminals of an electric cell called?
Match the materials with their types.
Explain why a bulb does not glow if its filament is broken.
content.answer: A bulb does not glow if its filament is broken because the filament is the part of the bulb that heats up and emits light when electricity passes through it. If the filament is broken, the circuit is incomplete, and electricity cannot flow through it.

content.statement: Electric current can flow through metals.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Device to open or close a circuit
The glowing part of a bulb
Does not allow current to pass

content.question: Draw a simple electric circuit with a switch, bulb, and cell.
content.answer: The drawing should include a cell, a bulb, and a switch connected in a closed loop to form a complete circuit.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: Materials that are attracted by magnets are called

content.question: Which direction does a freely suspended magnet always point to?
Match the poles of magnets with their interactions.
Describe how you can make a simple magnet using an iron nail and a bar magnet.

rubrics.title: Mention of using a single pole

content.answer: To make a simple magnet, take an iron nail and repeatedly stroke it with one pole of a bar magnet in the same direction. This aligns the domains within the nail, turning it into a magnet.

content.statement: A magnet always has two poles, North and South.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.
Circle the magnetic materials in the list.
Draw and label the process of making a magnet using an iron bar and a bar magnet.

rubrics.title: Correct labeling of the magnet and iron bar
Indication of the direction of stroking

content.answer: The drawing should depict an iron bar being stroked with a bar magnet in one direction, with labels indicating the magnet and the iron bar, and arrows showing the direction of stroking.

worksheet.subject: Science
worksheet.book: NCERT: Science - Textbook for Class VI

partitions.text: The gas that supports burning is called

content.question: What is the main component of air that does not support burning?
Match the components of air with their functions.
How does air become available to organisms living in soil?
content.answer: Air is present in the spaces between soil particles, allowing organisms to breathe.

content.statement: Plants and animals depend on each other for the exchange of gases.

content.question: Complete the crossword using clues about air components.
Label the composition of air.
content.answer: Labels should include Oxygen, Nitrogen, Carbon Dioxide, and Other Gases.

content.question: Circle the correct statements about air.
content.text:
Air is a mixture of gases.
It is visible and occupies space.
It supports life.
answers: Air is a mixture of gases

content.question: Draw a diagram showing the role of air in the water cycle.
content.answer: The diagram should show evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and air's role in these processes.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: Introduction: What, Where, How and When?
topics: Geographical locations and their historical significance

partitions.text: The word 'India' comes from the river called

content.question: What are manuscripts?
options: Handwritten records on palm leaves or birch bark

questions.topic: Geographical locations and their historical significance

content.question: Match the following locations with their historical significance.
Explain the difference between BC and AD.
content.answer: BC stands for 'Before Christ,' referring to the years before the birth of Jesus Christ. AD stands for 'Anno Domini,' a Latin phrase meaning 'in the year of our Lord,' referring to the years following the birth of Jesus Christ.

content.statement: Inscriptions are writings on soft surfaces like paper.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI

partitions.text: Hunter-gatherers moved from place to place because they would have eaten up all the

content.question: Which was the first animal to be domesticated by humans?
Why did early farmers need to stay in one place for a long time?
content.answer: Early farmers needed to stay in one place because they had to tend to their crops and domesticated animals, which required constant care and attention. This led to the development of permanent settlements.

content.statement: Mehrgarh is one of the earliest known villages where people grew barley and wheat.

content.question: Match the tools with their uses.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI

partitions.text: The Harappan cities were known for their advanced

content.question: What material was used by the Harappans to make beads?
Match the crops with their characteristics.
What are some theories about the decline of the Harappan cities?
content.answer: Some theories about the decline of Harappan cities include climate change leading to droughts, river course changes affecting agriculture, and possible invasions by other groups.

content.statement: The Harappan cities had a well-planned drainage system.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints given.
Circle the correct materials used by Harappans.
content.text: The Harappans used copper, gold, faience, and silver.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: What Books and Burials Tell Us

partitions.text: The Rigveda is composed of over a thousand hymns called

content.question: What are megaliths primarily used for?
Match the terms with their descriptions.
Describe the burial practices found at Inamgaon and their significance.
content.answer: Inamgaon burials were characterized by extended burials in pits, often with pottery and tools. These practices indicate social hierarchies and beliefs about the afterlife.

content.statement: The Rigveda was originally written down when it was first composed.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

wordPlacements.hint: Plant used for a special drink

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I
worksheet.chapterName: Kingdoms, Kings and An Early Republic

partitions.text: The ashvamedha was a ritual where a horse was let loose to wander freely and was guarded by the

content.question: What was one of the main reasons for collecting taxes in the mahajanapadas?
Match the social groups with their expected roles.
Explain how the use of iron ploughshares impacted agriculture.
content.answer: The use of iron ploughshares improved the efficiency of agriculture by making it easier to till hard soil, leading to increased agricultural productivity and surplus.

content.statement: Magadha was known for its powerful rulers like Bimbisara and Ajatasattu.

content.question: Complete the crossword with terms related to ancient kingdoms.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI

partitions.text: The Buddha attained enlightenment under a

content.question: What did Upanishadic thinkers believe about the atman and brahman?
options: Atman and Brahman are ultimately one.

content.question: Match the following terms with their meanings.
What was the main teaching of Mahavira?
content.answer: The main teaching of Mahavira was Ahimsa, which means non-violence. He emphasized that all living beings have a soul and should not be harmed. This principle is central to Jainism.

content.statement: The Buddha encouraged animal sacrifices.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: From a Kingdom to an Empire

partitions.text: from the area under the direct control of the ruler.

content.question: What was Ashoka's primary reason for adopting dhamma?
options: To reduce violence and promote peace

content.question: Match the following rulers with their contributions.
How did the Kalinga War change Ashoka's approach to governance?
content.answer: The Kalinga War was a turning point for Ashoka, leading him to embrace non-violence and adopt dhamma to promote peace and moral governance.

content.statement: The Mauryan Empire was smaller than the kingdoms that preceded it.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the hints provided.
Mark and label the major cities of the Mauryan Empire on the map.
content.answer: Pataliputra, Taxila, Ujjain

content.question: Circle the practices promoted by Ashoka's dhamma.
content.text:
Being gentle with slaves and servants
Respecting one's elders
Sacrificing animals
Treating all creatures with compassion
answers: Being gentle with slaves and servants

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I

partitions.text: The grama bhojaka was often the largest

content.question: What were punch-marked coins made of?
Match the Tamil terms with their meanings.
Describe the significance of iron tools in agriculture.
content.answer: Iron tools were significant in agriculture as they allowed for more efficient farming. They enabled deeper plowing of fields, which improved soil fertility and crop yields. Historically, the use of iron tools marked a shift towards more settled agricultural communities.

content.statement: The Silk Route was controlled by the Kushanas.

content.question: Complete the crossword using the clues about village life.
Circle the items that were exported from Barygaza.
content.text:
Wine
copper
tin
lead
ivory
agate
cotton
silk

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI
topics: Administration and military organization in ancient India
Role of local assemblies and hereditary officers

partitions.text: Samudragupta was a ruler from the

content.question: What is a 'prashasti'?
options: A eulogy written in praise of a king

questions.topic: Administration and military organization in ancient India

content.question: Describe the role of 'samantas' in the administration.
content.answer: Samantas were feudal lords who were granted land by the king and were responsible for maintaining their own armies. They played a crucial role in the administration by managing their territories and supporting the king in military campaigns.

questions.topic: Role of local assemblies and hereditary officers

content.statement: Hereditary officers were appointed for life.

content.question: Mark and label Prayaga, Pataliputra, and Ujjain on the map.
content.answer: Prayaga is located in the northern part of India, Pataliputra is in the eastern region, and Ujjain is in the central-western part of India.

worksheet.subject: History
worksheet.book: NCERT: Our Pasts-I - Textbook in History for Class VI
topics: Science and Mathematics in Ancient India

partitions.text: The iron pillar at Mehrauli is famous for not having

content.question: What is the main part of a Hindu temple called where the deity is placed?
Describe the significance of the paintings found in the Ajanta caves.
content.answer: The Ajanta paintings are significant for their depiction of Buddhist religious art, showcasing intricate details and vibrant colors. They illustrate the life of Buddha and Jataka tales, reflecting the rich cultural and religious history of ancient India.

content.statement: The Silappadikaram is a Sanskrit epic.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI
worksheet.chapterName: The Earth in the Solar System

partitions.text: The sun, the moon, and all those objects shining in the night sky are called

content.question: Which planet is known as Earth's twin?
Match the planets with their characteristics.
Why is Earth called a unique planet?
content.answer: Earth is called a unique planet because it has liquid water, a suitable atmosphere, and conditions that support life.

content.statement: The moon has its own light source.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints about galaxies.
Label the planets in the solar system diagram.
content.answer: Correctly label all planets in the correct order from the sun.

content.question: Circle the correct celestial body that is a planet.
Draw the phases of the moon.
content.answer: Draw the eight phases of the moon in correct sequence: New Moon, Waxing Crescent, First Quarter, Waxing Gibbous, Full Moon, Waning Gibbous, Last Quarter, Waning Crescent.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI
topics: Globe as a Model of Earth

partitions.text: The Prime Meridian is located at

content.question: Which zone receives the maximum heat?
Why is it necessary to have a standard time for a country?
content.answer: It is necessary to have a standard time for a country to ensure uniformity in time across different regions, facilitate scheduling in transportation and communication, and maintain national coordination.

questions.topic: Globe as a Model of Earth

content.statement: A globe is a true model of the Earth.

content.question: Label all the Important Latitudes and Heat Zones on the globe.
content.answer: The diagram should include labels for the Equator, Tropic of Cancer, Tropic of Capricorn, Arctic Circle, and Antarctic Circle, as well as the Torrid, Temperate, and Frigid Zones.

content.question: Draw a diagram showing the different heat zones on Earth.
content.answer: The drawing should clearly depict the Torrid Zone, Temperate Zones, and Frigid Zones, with accurate placement and labeling.

worksheet.subject: Geography
worksheet.book: NCERT: The Earth : Our Habitat - Textbook in Geography for Class VI

partitions.text: The Earth completes one rotation on its axis in

content.question: The Earth revolves around the sun in an orbit that is:
Match the following solstices with their characteristics.
Explain what happens during an equinox.

rubrics.title: Explanation of Day and Night Equality

content.answer: An equinox occurs when the plane of Earth's equator passes through the center of the Sun, resulting in nearly equal day and night durations. This happens twice a year, around March 21 and September 23.

content.statement: The Earth rotates from east to west.

content.question: Solve the crossword using the hints provided.

rubrics.title: Correct Indication of Earth's Axis Inclination

content.answer: The diagram should include labels for the Equator, Tropic of Cancer, Tropic of Capricorn, Arctic Circle, and Antarctic Circle, as well as the Earth's axis tilted at approximately 23.5 degrees.

content.question: Draw the Earth's orbit and label the positions for solstices and equinoxes.
content.answer: The drawing should show an elliptical orbit with the Earth at different positions marking the Summer Solstice, Winter Solstice, Spring Equinox, and Autumn Equinox.

worksheet.subject: Geography

partitions.text: The three components of a map are distance, direction, and

content.question: Which type of map shows natural features like mountains and rivers?

content.statement: A large scale map shows a larger area with less detail.

content.question: Explain how a compass can be used to find directions on a map.
content.answer: A compass is used to find directions by aligning its needle with the Earth's magnetic field. The needle points towards the magnetic north, allowing the user to determine other cardinal directions (east, west, south) relative to north. This helps in orienting the map correctly and navigating accurately.

content.question: Match the following map symbols with their meanings.
Draw all the 8 cardinal directions.
content.answer: The 8 cardinal directions are North, North-East, East, South-East, South, South-West, West, and North-West. The drawing should accurately represent these directions in a circular format, typically with North at the top.

content.question: Which gas makes up 78% of the Earth's atmosphere?
Explain why the Earth is called the 'blue planet'.

rubrics.title: Explains the significance of water bodies

content.answer: The Earth is called the 'blue planet' because about 71% of its surface is covered with water, which gives it a blue appearance from space.

content.statement: The biosphere is the zone where life exists on Earth.

content.question: Match the continents with their descriptions.
Label the continents and oceans on the world map.
content.answer: Continents: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia; Oceans: Pacific Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, Southern Ocean, Arctic Ocean.

content.question: Which form of government allows citizens to elect their leaders?
Match the level of government with its responsibility.
What is universal adult franchise and why is it important in a democracy?
content.answer: Universal adult franchise means that every adult citizen has the right to vote regardless of their gender, caste, education, or wealth. It is important in a democracy because it ensures equal participation in the governance process, reflecting the will of the people.

content.statement: In a monarchy, the monarch must explain their decisions to the people.

content.question: What is a Gram Sabha and who are its members?
content.answer: A Gram Sabha is a body consisting of persons registered in the electoral rolls relating to a village within the area of the Panchayat at the village level.

content.answer: The diagram should include the Gram Panchayat at the village level, the Panchayat Samiti at the block level, and the Zila Parishad at the district level.

content.question: What was the name of the space shuttle Kalpana Chawla flew on?
Describe Kalpana Chawla's educational background and how it led to her becoming an astronaut.

rubrics.title: Explanation of how education contributed to her career
Use of specific examples from the text

content.answer: Kalpana Chawla completed her Bachelor of Engineering degree in Aeronautical Engineering from Punjab Engineering College, India. She then moved to the United States to pursue a Master of Science degree in Aerospace Engineering from the University of Texas at Arlington. Her strong educational background in aerospace engineering and her dedication led her to become an astronaut at NASA.
